review.title: Discriminant chronicles mining: Application to care pathways analytics
review.abstract: Pharmaco-epidemiology (PE) is the study of uses and effects of drugs in well defined populations. As medico-administrative databases cover a large part of the population, they have become very interesting to carry PE studies. Such databases provide longitudinal care pathways in real condition containing timestamped care events, especially drug deliveries. Temporal pattern mining becomes a strategic choice to gain valuable insights about drug uses. In this paper we propose DCM, a new discriminant temporal pattern mining algorithm. It extracts chronicle patterns that occur more in a studied population than in a control population. We present results on the identification of possible associations between hospitalizations for seizure and anti-epileptic drug switches in care pathway of epileptic patients.
histories: Artificial Intelligence in Medicine, Jun 2017, Vienna, Austria. 2017, 16th Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Medicine
review.COMMENTS: Artificial Intelligence in Medicine, Jun 2017, Vienna, Austria. 2017, 16th Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Medicine

sections.text: Keywords: Temporal Pattern Mining, Knowledge Finding, Pharmacoepidemiology, Medical-Administrative Databases

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In fact, we are able to set out in search of a solution that will take us to another world.

sections.heading: 2 Discriminant chronicles
sections.text: This section presents basic definitions and defines the discriminatory role of mining in the Chronicle.

sections.heading: 2.1 Sequences and chronicles

sections.heading: 2.2 Chronicle support
sections.text: Let s = < (e1, t1), (en, tn) > be a sequence, and C = (E = {e ′ 1,..., e ′ m}, T) be a chronicle. An occurrence of C in s is a sub-sequence s = < (ef (1), tf (1),..., (ef (m), tf (m) > such that 1) f: [1, m] 7 → [1, n] is an injective function, 2), i, e ′ i = ef (i) and 3), i, j, tf (j) − tf (i), b] where e ′ i [a, b] e "j." T. It is worth noting that f does not necessarily increase. Indeed, there is a difference between (i) the sequence of the chronicle multideniz, and (ii) the sequence of events in the sequence C.

sections.heading: 2.3 Discriminant chronicles mining
sections.text: Let S + and S − be two sets of sequences, and σmin.

sections.heading: 3.1 Temporal constraints mining
sections.text: The general idea of ExtractDTC is to see the extraction of DTC as a classical numerical control task [3]. Let E = {e1... en} be a frequent multiset. A relational dataset, called D, is generated with all occurrences of E in S. The numerical attributes of D are cross-event durations between each pair (ei, ej), called Aei → ej. Each occurrence yields an example labeled with the sequence label (L, {+, −}). A rule algorithm induces numerical rules of D. A rule has a label as its conclusion and its premise is a conjunction of conditions to attribute values. Conditions are inequalities in the form: Aei → ej ≥ x Aei → ej ≤ ej ≤ y, where (x, y) the rules of R2 are translated. These rules are then called time constraints, ei [ej], which translate the chronic discrimination rate.

sections.heading: 4 Case study
sections.text: This section describes the use of DCM to study the pathways of epileptic patients. Recent studies suggest that drug substitutions (so-called switches) 7 may be associated with epileptic seizures in patients receiving long-term treatment with antiepileptic drugs (AE). In [12], the authors found no significant statistical association between brand-specific substitution and seizure-related hospitalization. The DCM algorithm is used to extract patterns of drug administration that distinguish the occurrence of more recent seizures, and these patterns may be of interest for further investigation by statistical analysis.

sections.heading: 4.1 Dataset
sections.text: Our data set was taken from the SNIIRAM database [11] for epileptic patients with stable AE treatment with at least one seizure event. Treatment is considered stable if the patient has administered at least 10 AE drugs within a year without having had a seizure. Epileptic seizures were identified by hospitalization associated with an epileptic event, encoded with G40.x or G41.x with ICD-105. The total number of such patients is 8,379. Each patient's treatment path is the collection of time-stamped drug deliveries from 2009 to 2011. For each drug administration, event identification is a tuple < m, grp, g > where the ATC code of the active molecule, g, {0, 1} and grp is the pre-administration specialty group. The specialty group identifies the drug presentation (international non-proprietary name, per unit strength, per pack containing 1,786 units and per pack of data set of each).

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: This article introduces a new task for the study of temporal patterns, the extraction of discriminatory chronicles, and the DCM algorithm that extracts them from temporal sequences. This new task seems useful for analyzing supply routes in the context of pharmacoepidemiological studies, and we are following the Polard et al. [12] study of epileptic patients with this new approach. On the one hand, extracted patterns are discriminatory, corresponding to supply sequences that are more closely related to a particular outcome, i.e. epileptic seizures in our case study. Such patterns are fewer in number and more interesting to physicians. 10On the other hand, the most important contribution of the DCM algorithm is the discovery of temporal information that discriminates care sequences. Even if a sequence of care events is non-discriminatory (e.g. drug change), the way they occur over time can testify to the outcome (e.g. seizure).

metadata.abstractText: Pharmaco-epidemiology (PE) is the study of uses and effects of drugs in well defined populations. As medico-administrative databases cover a large part of the population, they have become very interesting to carry PE studies. Such databases provide longitudinal care pathways in real condition containing timestamped care events, especially drug deliveries. Temporal pattern mining becomes a strategic choice to gain valuable insights about drug uses. In this paper we propose DCM , a new discriminant temporal pattern mining algorithm. It extracts chronicle patterns that occur more in a studied population than in a control population. We present results on the identification of possible associations between hospitalizations for seizure and anti-epileptic drug switches in care pathway of epileptic patients.
